application watering in of chemicals shall not exceed onefourthinch of water per application except as otherwise required by law the manufacturer or best management practices 4 irrigation systems may be operated any time of day on any day for maintenance and repair purposes not to exceed 20 minutes per hour per zone 5 irrigation using a handheld hose equipped with an automatic shutoff nozzle is allowed at any time of day on any day 6 discharge of water from a watertoair conditioning unit or other waterdependent cooling system is not limited 7 the use of water from a reclaimed water system is allowed anytime for the purpose of this paragraph a reclaimed water system includes systems in which the primary source is reclaimed water which may or may not be supplemented from another source during peak demand periods 8 the use of recycled water from wet detention treatment ponds for irrigation is allowed anytime provided the ponds are not augmented from any ground or offsite surface water or public supply sources excess demand and water supply emergencies 1 excess demand level one when excess demand is determined water pressure may be lowered and the citys water supply customers shall only irrigate between the hours of  midnight and  am 2 excess demand level two when severe excess demand is determined water pressure may be further lowered and the citys water supply customers shall only irrigate between the hours of  am and  am 3 water supply emergency when a water supply emergency is determined all use of the citys water supply by the citys water supply customers beyond that necessary for maintenance of health and safety is prohibited in the affected area and no irrigation by the citys water supply customers is permitted  6209 variances from specific day of the week limitations or from excess demandwater supply emergency provisions the city council may grant variances to the landscape irrigation schedule and the excess demandwater supply emergency provisions set forth above in respectively under the following conditions 1 a variance from the specific landscape irrigation days or day set forth in may be granted if strict application of the scheduled days or day would lead to unreasonable or unfair results in particular instances provided that the applicant demonstrates with particularity that compliance with the schedule of days or day for landscape irrigation will result in a substantial economic health or other hardship on the applicant requesting the variance or those served by the applicant where a contiguous property is divided into different zones a variance may be granted hereunder so that each zone may be irrigated on different days or day than other zones of the property however in no event shall a variance allow a single zone to be irrigated more than two days per week during daylight savings time or more than one day per week during eastern standard time 2 when specified hours of customer irrigation during an excess demand or water supply emergency would result in undue hardship for a specific customer 3 all users or customers requesting a variance as set forth above shall file with the city manager a petition for variance but must conform to the greatest possible extent to the provisions of this article until such variance is granted 4 a petition for variance shall be in writing and contain at a minimum the following a the petitioners name and address b a detailed statement of the facts which the petitioner believes demonstrates that the request qualifies for variance c a description of the variance desired d the period of time for which the variance is sought including the reasons and facts in support thereof e other relevant information the petitioner believes supports hisher petition for variance 5 variances granted under the provisions of this be issued in writing  6209 additional requirement any person who irrigates landscape with an automatic lawn sprinkler system installed after  shall install maintain and operate a rain sensor device or switch that overrides the irrigation system when adequate rainfall has occurred when reclaimed water is available the use of a private irrigation well for landscape irrigation is not authorized under subsection 40c2 fac reclaimed water is deemed available when reclaimed water is provided by a utility point of connection  6209 application of article the provisions of this article shall apply to each person located within the city of palm coast  6209 enforcement officials law enforcement officials having jurisdiction in the area governed by this article are hereby authorized to enforce the provisions of this article in addition the city manager may also delegate enforcement responsibility for this article to various departments of the city of palm coast government  6209 penalties any person found guilty of a violation of any provision of this article or any lawful order of the city council or city manager or hisher duly authorized representative shall be punished by a maximum $50000 fine or 60 days imprisonment or by both a fine and imprisonment the city may also enforce this article by any means available under the provisions of controlling law and may seek any available legal remedy  6209 article vi  prohibition of discharges intent and purpose a it is the intent and purpose of the city council of the city of palm coast to prohibit activities that result in the depositing eg illicit discharging into the waters of the city of any hazardous material liquid or pollutant that by itself or in combination with other activities or substances would impair the environmental integrity of a body of water or bodies of water or may cause or significantly contribute to a substantial present or potential hazard to human health safety property or the environment  or impair or adversely impact the recreational use or other public use of a body of water located within the city following the federal clean water act 33 usc 1251 et seq and municipal separate storm sewer systems rules fac ch 62624 pursuant to the authority of fs   as guidelines b it is not the intent of the city council of the city of palm coast to prohibit lawfully permitted activities for which a valid and current permit has been issued by an agency of competent jurisdiction c it is the intent of the city council of the city of palm coast to ensure that use of docks and related facilities or structures located on or along the waters of the city occurs in a manner that is conducive to the public interest which protects the environment and natural resources and is otherwise in the public interest  2304   3 11618 definitions the following words and phrases shall have the meanings as hereinafter defined when used in this article a best management practices means and includes but is not limited to scheduled activities prohibitions practices general good housekeeping practices pollution prevention and educational practices maintenance procedures treatment requirements operating procedures design specifications and other management practices that are generally accepted in the field that are intended to prevent or reduce pollutants from entering the city stormwater system or being discharged from the city stormwater system b clean water act or cwa means 33 usc 1251 et seq as amended c construction and demolition debris means discarded materials generally considered to be not watersoluble and nonhazardous in nature including but not limited to steel glass brick concrete asphalt roofing material pipe gypsum wallboard and lumber from the construction or destruction of a structure as part of a construction or demolition project or from the renovation of a structure and includes rocks soils tree remains trees and other vegetative matter that normally results from land clearing or land development operations for a construction project including such debris from construction of structures at a site remote from the construction or demolition project site mixing of construction and demolition debris with other types of solid waste will cause the resulting mixture to be classified as other than construction and demolition debris the term also includes 1 clean cardboard paper plastic wood and metal scraps from a construction project  2 except as provided in fs 9 j yard trash and unpainted nontreated wood scraps and wood pallets from sources other than construction or demolition projects  3 scrap from manufacturing facilities which is the type of material generally used in construction projects and which would meet the definition of construction and demolition debris if it were generated as part of a construction or demolition project this includes debris from the construction of manufactured homes and scrap shingles wallboard siding concrete and similar materials from industrial or commercial facilities d garbage means any waste accumulation of animal fruit or vegetable matter used or intended for food or that accompanies the preparation use cooking processing handling or storage of meat fish fowl fruit or vegetables or any other matter which is subject to decomposition decay putrefaction and the generation of offensive and noxious gases or odors e hazardous materials means any material including but not limited to any substance waste or combination thereof which because of its quantity concentration or physical chemical or infectious characteristics may cause or significantly contribute to a substantial present or potential hazard to human health safety property or the environment when improperly treated stored transported disposed of or otherwise managed f hazardous waste  means any solid waste or a combination of solid wastes which because of its quantity concentration or physical chemical or infectious characteristics may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness or may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly transported disposed of stored treated or otherwise managed the term does not include human remains that are disposed of by persons licensed under fs ch 497 g illicit connection means a point source discharge to the citys stormwater system or to waters of the united states which is not composed entirely of stormwater or which is not authorized by a permit h illicit discharge means any discharge to the citys stormwater system or to waters of the united states which is not composed entirely of stormwater unless exempted pursuant to this regulation or an npdes permit i liquid means any and all types of liquids except rainwater j litter means all waste and discarded materials including but not limited to glass cans scrap metal paper plastic rubber garbage building materials disposable packages or containers chemicals or deleterious materials not properly disposed k litter receptacle means a container with a capacity of not less than ten gallons constructed and placed for use as a depository for litter l material means and includes but is not limited to dirt bricks grass clippings lumber trash yard debris or wood m person means a natural person or individual or any firm corporation association club society or other organization n point source means any discernible and confined conveyance including but not limited to any pipe ditch channel conduit well container rolling stocks concentrated animal feeding operation vessel or other floating craft from which pollutants are discharged this term does not include return flows from irrigated agriculture o pollutant means anything which causes or contributes to pollution which may include but is not limited to petroleum products including but not limited to oil gasoline and grease solid waste dredged soil refuse rubbish garbage litter debris paints varnishes steam cleaning waste pesticides herbicides or fertilizers degreasers solvents  hazardous substances and wastes dissolved and particulate metals sanitary sewage filter backwash sewage sludge fecal coliform and pathogens wastewater radioactive materials except those regulated under the atomic energy act of 1954 as amended 42 usc 2011 et seq chemically treated cooling water chemical wastes incinerator residue antifreeze and other automotive products lawn clippings leaves branches etc animal carcasses and wastes biological materials munitions heat wrecked or damaged equipment rock sand and industrial excepting the countys discharges recreational vehicle waters dyes noxious or offensive matter construction materials any liquids in quantity or quality which are capable of causing a violation of the citys npdes stormwater permit  and solids in such quantities or of such size capable of causing interference or obstruction to the flow in the citys stormwater system ms4 not excluding other materials which the city manager or designee federal or state regulatory agencies may deem appropriate to be included p waters of the city means lakes ponds impoundments the intracoastal waterway streams or any other body of water or waterway or any tributary to said bodies of water or waterways located within the city limits of the city of palm coast or abutting the city limits of the city of palm coast q water or waters in the state means any and all water on or beneath the surface of the ground or in the atmosphere including natural or artificial watercourses lakes ponds or diffused surface water and water percolating standing or flowing beneath the surface of the ground as well as all coastal waters within the jurisdiction of the state fs  22 r wetland means those areas inundated or saturated by surface or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support and under normal circumstances do support a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soils soils present in wetlands generally are classified as hydric or alluvial or possess characteristics that are associated with reducing soil conditions the prevalent vegetation in wetlands generally consists of facultative or obligate hydrophytic macrophytes that are typically adapted to areas having soil conditions described above these species due to morphological physiological or reproductive adaptations have the ability to grow reproduce or persist in aquatic environments or anaerobic soil conditions florida wetlands generally include swamps marshes bayheads bogs cypress domes and strands sloughs wet prairies riverine swamps and marshes hydric seepage slopes tidal marshes mangrove swamps and other similar areas florida wetlands generally do not include longleaf or slash pine flatwoods with an understory dominated by saw palmetto the landward extent of wetlands is delineated pursuant to fac as ratified by fs   30 fac  2304   3 11618 prohibited actsobligations and duties a no discharge to the citys stormwater system ms4 shall be permitted to impair the operation of the ms4 or contribute to the failure of the ms4 to meet any local state or federal requirements including but not limited to npdes permits b any person determined by the city to be responsible for a discharge contributing to the failure of the citys ms4 to comply with the provisions and conditions of an npdes permit shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall provide corrective measures as determined necessary by the city manager or designee and shall be responsible for fines and damages as indicated in subsection 1 below c prohibition of illicit discharges and illicit connections  1 illicit discharges and illicit connections to the citys ms4 are prohibited 2 failure to report a connection to the citys ms4 or to waters of the united states from industrial activities commercial entities or construction activities constitutes an illicit connection 3 failure to report to the city a discharge to the citys ms4 or to waters of the united states from industrial activities commercial entities or construction activities constitutes an illicit discharge 4 any discharge to the citys ms4 or to waters of the united states which is in violation of federal state or local permits or regulations constitutes an illicit discharge 5 persons responsible for illicit discharges or illicit connections shall immediately cease the illicit discharge or illicit connection and obtain appropriate approvals from applicable regulatory agencies prior to resuming the discharge or connection d inspection and monitoring for compliance city personnel shall be granted access for inspection of facilities discharging or suspected of discharging to the citys ms4 or waters of the united states in order to effectuate the provisions of this chapter and to investigate violations or potential violations of any of the terms herein all structures and processes which allow discharges to the citys ms4 as well as records concerning them shall be made accessible to the citys personnel for this purpose e maintenance of structures structural control and other bmps used for controlling the discharge of pollutants to the citys ms4 or to waters of the united states shall be operated and maintained so as to function in accordance with permitted design and performance criteria and in compliance with federal state or local permit conditions and regulations f exemptions discharges from the following activities shall not be considered an illicit discharge or illicit connection unless such activities cause or significantly contribute to the impairment of the use of the citys ms4 or the violation of the conditions of the citys npdes permit the following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions established by this article 1 water line flushing  2 flushing of reclaimed water lines  3 street cleaning  4 sidewalkbuilding power washing that does not utilize chemicals detergents etc  5 construction dust control  6 landscape irrigation  7 diverted stream flows or lake waters  8 foundation footing and roof drains not including active groundwater dewatering systems  9 uncontaminated groundwater infiltration as defined in 40 cfr 20  10 discharges from potable water sources  11 air conditioning condensate or cooling water  12 springs  13 lawn watering  14 individual residential car washing  15 flows from riparian habitat surface waters and wetlands  16 discharges or flow from emergency firefighting activities and emergency response activities done in accordance with adopted spill responseaction plan  17 fertilizers and pesticides applied for normal lawn treatment and maintenance  18 discharges specified in writing by the authorized federal state or other applicable enforcement agency as being necessary to protect public health and safety  and 19 the prohibition shall not apply to any nonstormwater discharge permitted under a national pollutant discharge elimination system npdes or industrial wastewater treatment iwwt permit waiver or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered under the authority of the environmental protection agency epa or florida department of environmental protection fdep provided that the discharger is in full compliance with all requirements of the permit waiver or order and other applicable laws and regulations and provided that written approval or all necessary permits have been granted for any discharge into waters of the city g it shall be unlawful for any person to drain deposit place or otherwise discharge pollutants into any stormwater system within the city or to cause or permit to be drained deposited placed or otherwise discharged into such stormwater systems any organic or inorganic matter which causes pollution pursuant to the water quality standards established by all applicable regulatory agencies h it shall be unlawful to wash any public or private streets buildings sidewalks or parking areas unless all visible debris and sediments have been removed prior to washing if the removal of the debris and sediments is not feasible as determined by the land use administrator then the street building sidewalk or parking area may only be washed with the city engineers written approval which may include requirements to clean the affected drainage pipelines or provide treatment of wastewater to prevent downstream pollution i it is unlawful for a person in charge of or occupying a vessel docked at or moored to land docks piers or wharfs abutting waters of the city to fail to observe the applicable health and sanitary laws rules and regulations relating to such activities and waters which prohibit acts contrary to the public health safety morals or welfare j the city shall take all appropriate actions relating to vessels that are abandoned in waters of the city and shall coordinate its activities with the florida fish and wildlife conservation commission in accordance with the provisions of state law k it is the obligation and duty of all persons to utilize best management practices in conducting activities abutting on or proximate to the waters of the city and it is unlawful for a person to fail to use best management practices as required l construction site refuse solid waste and litter 1 owner agent and contractor shall not permit the accumulation of litter before during or after completion of any construction or demolition project 2 it shall be the responsibility of the owner agent and contractor to provide litter receptacles and prevent scattering of litter on a daily basis all litter shall be removed from construction sites not less than once a week 3 no person shall place any refuse recyclable materials trash garbage cans or trash bags on upon or over any storm drain or so close thereto as to be drawn by the elements into a storm drain which would result in or tend to cause a blockage of any part of such storm drainage system 4 it shall be the responsibility of owners or agents to keep areas free of garbage trash etc the owners agents tenants or lessees of all property whether improved or unimproved including residential homes apartment units and businesses shall be responsible for complying with the provisions of this chapter the owners agents tenants or lessees shall be severally and jointly responsible for keeping the following areas free from garbage solid waste recyclable materials and refuse at all times exclusive of those periods immediately prior to collection such areas to include the entire premises as well as the roadway swale and easement adjoining the property 5 builders building contractors construction tradesmen and homeowners shall be responsible for removing all excavation construction and demolition wastes emanating from their work and shall use vehicles designed or outfitted so as to prevent the wastes carried therein from being blown dropped or spilled from such vehicles m 1 any persons convicted of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred and no100 dollars $50000 plus costs of prosecution or by imprisonment for not more than sixty days or by both fine and costs and imprisonment in the discretion of the court 2 the provisions of this section may be enforced by any and all lawful means by the city pursuant to all codes and ordinances duly adopted by the city council or as may otherwise be available to the city pursuant to state law and nothing in this the city from enforcing this section by other means set forth in the citys codes and ordinances provided in the statutory law of the state of florida or otherwise available to the city  2304   3 11618 article vii  abandoned or derelict vessels intent a it is the intent of the city council of the city of palm coast to provide for the abatement as necessary of abandoned unattended or derelict vessels on the waters of the city and to promote the health safety and welfare of the general public and the citizens of the city it is further the intent of the city council to protect the quality of water and other natural resources of the city the city council declares that the abandonment or the improper disposal of abandoned unattended or derelict vessels constitutes a public nuisance b it is not the intent of this article to in any way deviate from the provisions of chapters 327 or 328 or or florida statutes relating to derelict vessels to restrict any action on behalf of the state of florida or to delegate additional authority to the city of palm coast regarding derelict vessels other than as specifically set forth herein it is the intent of the this article to further the policy of the state of florida set forth in of the constitution of the state of florida relating to natural resources and scenic beauty which provides in pertinent part that it shall be the policy of the state to conserve and protect its natural resources and scenic beauty adequate provision shall be made by law for the abatement of air and water pollution and of excessive and unnecessary noise and for the conservation and protection of natural resources c it is the intent of this article to supplement existing regulations of abandoned and derelict watercraft found in section 41608 of the citys unified land development  42109 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning abandoned unattended vessel means any unattended vessel in or on the waters of the city 1 which is adrift  2 that is found in a badly deteriorated condition or is taking on water or is sinking or partially sunk or sunk  3 that is causing damage to private or public property  4 that is releasing contaminants or chemicals into water  5 that is or was on fire  6 that is a menace to navigation  or 7 that is unattended for a period greater than 72 hours city means the city of palm coast florida city manager means the palm coast city manager or designee derelict vessel means any vessel that is 1 left stored or abandoned in a wrecked junked or substantially dismantled condition upon any public waters of the city or 2 docked grounded at or beached upon private property in a wrecked junked or substantially dismantled condition or 3 docked or grounded at or beached upon the property of another without the consent of the owner of the property owner means a person who holds the legal title in or to a vessel other than a lienholder the term includes a person entitled to the use or possession of a vessel subject to an interest in another person reserved or created by agreement and securing payment of performance of an obligation but the term excludes a lessee under a lease not intended as security unattended vessel is any vessel that has no person on board vessel is synonymous with boat as referenced in s1b art vii of the state constitution and includes every description of watercraft barge and airboat other than a seaplane on the water used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water waters of the city means lakes ponds impoundments streams canals or any other natural or manmade body of water or waterway or any tributary to said bodies of water or waterways located within the defined city limits of the city of palm coast  42109 abandoned or derelict vessels  removal from city waters a the city manager is hereby authorized to take any and all necessary actions in conjunction with state and local law enforcement agencies to remove and impound any abandoned unattended or derelict vessel from waters of the city b the city manager is hereby authorized to take any and all necessary actions to apply for funding from florida fish and wildlife conservation commission and its program providing grants to local governments for the removal of abandoned unattended or derelict vessels from the public waters of the state c all actual city costs for removal towing and storage will be assessed to the owner if the vessel is unclaimed it shall be disposed as provided in state statutes ref florida statutes and may be retained by the city for official use or sold with the proceeds paying for the charges incurred with the remainder of the funds to be used solely by the city for the education and enforcement of marine related laws ref  32866 florida statutes to the extent allowed by law failure to act on the part of the owner waives all liability of the city from damages as a result from towing and storage  42109 prohibited acts it is unlawful to dock or moor an abandoned unattended or derelict vessel to land docks piers or wharfs located in waters of the city  42109 further penalties and remedies a in addition to the relief provided in subsections 24253a and c any person violating any of the provisions of this article may be punished to the maximum extent as provided in state law as set forth in florida statutes and other controlling legal authority b all persons participating in or contributing to a violation of this article shall be in violation c the city may engage in any other code enforcement activities and processes as it deems appropriate under the circumstances and may seek judicial and administrative remedies as deemed appropriate by the city d each act of violation of this article shall constitute a separate violation e relating to any noncriminal penalty provided for herein and to the extent permitted by state law the property owner of a dock pier wharf or boatlift shall be rebuttably presumed to have allowed any derelict or abandoned unattended vessel attached to such to have been attached with the consent of the property owner and the property owner may only rebut such presumption by a preponderance of the evidence to the contrary the property owner of a dock pier marina facility wharf or boatlift shall be responsible for compliance with all laws codes and ordinances relating to the maintenance of such facilities as well as any and all vessels attached thereto or associated therewith  42109 fire prevention and protection footnotes  1  cross reference administration ch 2  buildings and building regulations ch 15  businesses and business regulations ch 16  emergency services ch 23  environment ch 24 state law reference fire prevention and control generally fs chs 553 633 article i  in general enforcement of fire safety laws the building department shall enforce all fire safety laws  3700 fire safety and rescue a creation of the city of palm coast fire rescue departmentfire rescue service area there is hereby created and established within the city of palm coast governmental structure a city of palm coast fire rescue department there is hereby created and established within the city limits of the city of palm coast as they may be from timetotime revised and amended in accordance with the controlling provisions of florida law a city of palm coast fire rescue service area which shall be consistent with the city limits of the city of palm coast b ratification of prior acts all actions taken by the city council of the city of palm coast relative to the city of palm coast fire rescue department prior to the effective date of this section and all actions of the city of palm coast fire rescue department occurring prior to the effective date of this section are hereby ratified and affirmed c operations of outside agencies within city limits with the exception of the division of forestry of the florida department of agriculture and consumer services and other governmental agencies acting under that departments authority under florida statutes the only situations in which outside governmental agencies may enter the city limits of the city of palm coast to provide fire rescue fire suppression basic life support advanced life support public education code enforcement hazardous material response and mitigation training testing and other emergency and public safety response functions shall be when the city of palm coast fire rescue department formally requests the other agency to provide services within the city of palm coast citys fire chief or designee or pursuant to the terms and conditions of a first response or mutual aid agreement between the city of palm coast and the other governmental agency as approved by the city council of the city of palm coast it is prohibited and unlawful to interfere with the operations of the city of palm coast fire rescue department within the city limits of the city of palm coast the provisions of this section shall not apply to ambulance service d penalties the city of palm coast may pursue any code enforcement action available under controlling state law and any legal remedy available to the city to include but not be limited to a fine not exceeding $50000 unless otherwise authorized by state law or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days unless otherwise authorized by state law or by both such fine and imprisonment  32106 editors note  adopted  added provisions that were not specifically amendatory at the editors discretion said provisions have been included herein as  253 article ii  fire prevention division 1  generally automatic fire sprinkler systems required a automatic fire sprinkler systems shall be required in all new construction located in the city exceeding 10000 square feet in floor area b automatic fire sprinkler systems shall be required in existing buildings when any new addition creates an aggregate floor area exceeding 10000 square feet the aggregate floor area consists of the existing building plus the new addition the automatic fire sprinkler systems shall be required in the entire building once it exceeds 10000 square feet in floor area c exceptions are as follows 1 agricultural barns and pole barns 2 airport hangars used for aircraft storage only not exceeding 10000 square feet in floor area 3 residential singlefamily and multiunit structures four or less units d automatic fire sprinklers shall be installed tested inspected and maintained to the specifications of national fire protection association standards 13 13d or 13r whichever applies  3700   6402 division 2  fire code standard fire prevention the 1988 edition of the standard fire prevention including all appendices thereto is adopted by reference  3700 local amendments to fire prevention to burning the following local amendments to the fire prevention are based upon the recitals set forth in the provisions of this section and shall provide additional fire prevention standards within the city limits of the city of palm coast and shall supplement the florida fire prevention in the event of any conflict between a provision of this local amendment and the florida fire prevention this local amendment shall prevail this local amendment shall be incorporated into the florida fire prevention the in conjunction with the citys fire marshal 1 open burning prohibited a open burning of commercial waste residential trash garbage lawn debris clippings trees or other debris on residential commercial or industrial property is prohibited within the city limits of the city of palm coast but not including commercial land clearing operations which is addressed in subsection b b the following types of open burning are permitted if preapproved by the fire marshal and a permit issued by the fire marshal for such activities which approval may occur in the context of a preannexation agreement and which permits shall focus on addressing the disbursal of smoke and its adverse affects 1 ceremonial fires 2 commercial land clearing operations 3 prescribed burns conducted by fire control agencies 4 when an emergency condition exists within the city that warrants burning 5 campfires c permits for open burning relating to commercial land clearing operations shall be issued by the fire marshal upon finding that 1 all conditions precedent to lawful burning have been met and 2 the florida division of forestry has been notified of the burning and 3 that the burn index of the florida division of forestry will permit burning on the day or days for which an open burning permit is requested d the following types of open burning do not require permitting by the fire marshal and are permitted if conducted in a safe manner and without the creation of a nuisance 1 outdoor fireplaces kilns ovens or other similarly approved devices 2 outdoor cooking fires that are engaged in bona fide food provision are constantly attended while cooking food and are no larger than three feet in diameter with flames no higher than three feet 3 warming fires conducted at work sites in a metal barrel when the temperature is below 45 degrees fahrenheit 2 permits for open burning a applications for open burning permits shall be on forms to be provided by the fire rescue department b the city council may by adoption of a resolution establish an application fee for an open burning permits for each day or part thereof on which any open burning occurs or as otherwise established by resolution of the city council the applicant for a permit shall provide the fire marshal with an estimate of the number of days on which the burning will occur and pay in advance the application fee for that estimated number if the actual number of days is less than the said estimate the permit holder shall be entitled to an appropriate refund if a longer period of open burning is required the applicant shall obtain a permit for all such additional days in the same manner as for the initial permit prior to continuation of the open burning and may not continue burning under the permit c nothing herein shall relieve any person from complying with any other applicable law rule registration and ordinance relating to open burning  41806 editors note  adopted  added provisions that were not specifically amendatory at the editors discretion said provisions were included herein as  2552 article iii  enforcement footnotes the table enforcement responsibility the fire marshal shall be responsible for the enforcement of the fire safety code the fire chief may detail qualified inspectors as shall from time to time be occurring in the city by which property has been destroyed or damaged and so far as possible shall determine whether the fire is the result of carelessness or design such investigations shall begin immediately upon the occurrence of such a fire the fire marshal shall take charge immediately of the physical evidence shall notify the proper authorities designated by law to pursue the investigation of such matters and shall further cooperate with the authorities in the collection of evidence and in the prosecution of the case  3700   101601 authority to remedy fire safety code violations a an inspector possesses the authority to protect property and persons whenever there is found violations of the fire and life safety codes b an order under this part shall be served on the occupant or person in charge of the premises or by affixing the order on the entrance door to the premises whenever it is necessary to serve the record owner of the premises with the order and such owner is not available personally then the inspector shall mail the order by certified mail return receipt requested to the owners last known address such mailing shall be supplemental to posting the order on the entrance door to the premises  3700   101601 conflicts between fire codes and building codes shall be resolved as set forth in fs  553738a e or its successor  101601 permits a permit is required for commercial hood extinguishing systems or other private fire protection systems 2 the installation of any fire alarm detection or fire communication system exception detached one and twofamily dwellings 3 any public fireworks display any owner contractor or authorized agent who desires a permit required under this code shall first make application to the building department of the city to obtain said permit including the necessary plans licenses fees and other related documents  101601 fees fees shall be established by resolution for the permits certificates approvals and other all appendices all fire protection codes adopted to establish alternative requirements on a casebycase basis in order to meet special situations arising from historic geographic or unusual conditions provided the alternative requirements result in a level of protection to life safety or property equal to or greater than the applicable code or standard the fire marshal shall be designated as the authority having jurisdiction as defined and outlined in the various adopted codes and standards  101601 article iv  wildfire hazard mitigation findings the city council hereby makes the following findings a palm coast is a 42000 acre planned development situated in coastal plain flatwoods prior to its development the land was actively managed for southern pine timber production timber management included the periodic use of prescribed burns to control vegetative fuel buildup b palm coast has a densely developed core in which homes have been built sporadically throughout the development prescribed fires are no longer used for timber management c in may 198 a wildfire burned city destroying 100 homes and damaging 200 others a study conducted by the florida division of forestry concluded that fire crowning in the pine tree canopy a buildup of brush within 30 feet of a residential structure and a general buildup of fuels from decaying vegetation significantly correlated to the destruction or damage of a residential structure d in the summer of 1998 a devastating wildfire again burned city due to drought and the accumulation of brush destroying and damaging many homes and community infrastructure the same factors were associated with increased fire losses e fighting fires in the intermix between pine plantation timberlands and rural residential development requires different fire suppression strategies and equipment relying on suppression may not be reliable because it is a minor component in determining the loss of property more important factors are weather conditions vegetation structural characteristics and accessibility f many homeowners and landowners do not or cannot adopt mitigation measures such as brush clearance and fire resistant roofing material public education is hampered because the city has a very rapid rate of population growth and a number of the homes in the community are only seasonally occupied g state law authorizes the florida division of forestry to conduct prescribed burns as a mitigation measure on private lands such prescribed burning however is of limited utility because of the spreading and scattering of new homes being built in the pine plantation h to further promote hazard mitigation the city is required to exercise its power in coordination with the state of florida division of forestry to address wildfire hazard mitigation effective hazard mitigation to address the evolution of the citys development from a pine plantation to a residential community includes selective mowing of brush where prescribed burning is not adequate or feasible i the state division of forestry and the city have the capability to identify areas that have a relatively severe risk of wildfire hazard and to prioritize those areas for systematic mitigation planning and implementation j such systematic mitigation measures are necessary to avoid catastrophic loss to the community economically and in the quality of life k such systematic mitigation to the extent it limits wildfire damage also will help the community conserve its natural resources for aesthetic environmental and stormwater management purposes l the risk of wildfire recurrence is substantial under expected climatic conditions weather patterns associated with increased fire activity are a part of the el ninola nina southern oscillation phenomena that the city can expect to experience on a recurring basis as southern pacific sea surface temperatures drop fire activity in florida increases  41701 definitions as used in this article the following terms shall have the following meanings unless a different meaning is clearly intended brush shall mean plant species that by virtue of their arrangement chemical composition and growth pattern provide a ready path for uncontrolled fire to spread species included in this definition include saw palmetto gallberry fetterbush and wax myrtle pine trees less than five inches diameter breast height four and onehalf feet above grade are included in this definition fire hazard shall mean brush or other vegetation which by reason of their nature location or condition may cause loss damage or injury to persons or property by reason of fire brush on undeveloped lots averaging over three feet tall within 30 feet of an existing residential structure is considered a fire hazard lot tract or parcel includes the adjacent unpaved portions of the street rightofway and the property owners adjacent properties remedies or corrective measures as referred to in this article remedies or corrective measures shall include but not be limited to the city removing the brush located on the property and adjacent street rightofway or removing the unlawful fire hazard on the property and adjacent street rightofway street shall mean any public street road highway freeway lane path public way or place sidewalk alley court boulevard parkway drive or easement now or hereafter held by the city for the purpose of public travel undeveloped vacant lot shall mean any lot or parcel that does not contain a structure andor improvement this shall also include adjacent property where both parcels are owned by one person or entity but only if said adjacent property is located within 200 feet of a developed lot  41701 designation of hazardous properties the city manager or designee will identify undeveloped lots determined to constitute a fire hazard the city manager or designee shall develop a plan for hazard mitigation for the identified area which shall include public education the plan may include selective mowing of brush determined to constitute a fire hazard pursuant to this article the city shall notify owners of property within the identified area who have fire hazards and shall inform such owners of the action required to be taken such properties that contain fire hazards shall be public nuisances  41701 unlawful fire hazard allowing brush to accumulate on any undeveloped lot tract or parcel of land shall be unlawful where it is held by the city manager or designee to constitute a fire hazard under section 25103 and is hereby prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance it shall be the owners responsibility to remedy the violation constituting a fire hazard this section shall include the property owners adjacent properties as well as the adjacent street rightofway  41701 violation to permit unlawful fire hazard any owner lessee or occupant of any lot tract or parcel of land in the city who permits a fire hazard consisting of brush on any undeveloped lot to the extent and in the manner that it creates a fire hazard shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished according to law  41701 reserved editors note a adopted feb 1 200 repealed  25106 which pertained to fire mitigation review board and derived from  adopted  b states the duties of the fire mitigation review board are hereby assigned to the city of palm coast board with all actions pertaining to fire mitigation being taken in conformity to the provisions of the laws ordinances rules and procedures applicable to the board at the editors discretion in accordance with the provisions of b all references within this article to the fire mitigation review board have been changed to the board notice by city to owner of record of violation  requirement to remedy violation  copy of notice to owner a if property is designated a fire hazard and a public nuisance under sections 25103 and 25104 a notice shall be given to the owner andor operator of the property at their last known address as shown upon the records of the flagler county property appraiser by certified mail or hand delivery if an attempt to reach the owner andor operator by hand delivery or certified mail is unsuccessful the notice shall be given by physical posting on the property in the name of the property owner as shown upon the records of the flagler county property appraiser and notice shall also be posted at city hall and sent by first class mail to the address shown by the property appraiser b the notice to the owner andor operator shall advise of the condition found to exist on the property described in said notice and require that the owner either cause such condition to be remedied forthwith or that the owner authorize the city to have such work done on behalf of the owner at their cost or as a lien against the property the notice shall detail the specific violations of which the owner is charged shall detail the specific remedies that are necessary to correct the violations and shall give the owner 30 calendar days from the date of the notice to remedy the violation the notice to owner shall provide that the property owner or their agent or representative may request a hearing before the board within 30 calendar days of the posting or mailing of the notice by the city by completing the appropriate form and paying a filing fee of $5000 this filing fee shall be refunded if the owner is the prevailing party in the action before the board as provided in section 25110  41701   2105 failure of owner to mitigate if the owner of the affected property or any agent acting on behalf of the owner thereof fails to request a hearing to protest such action before the board before the date specified in the notice to the owner and fails to take corrective action within the time specified in the aforesaid notice the city manager or designee may direct the appropriate department of the city to remedy the violation by having the existing condition corrected alternatively the city manager may refer to the city attorney to seek an injunction to authorize appropriate mitigation of the fire hazard including prescribed burns  41701   2105 hearing before board at the hearing before the board the owner agent or representative may appear before the board to show the board that the condition mentioned in the notice does not exist or to show why said brush does not constitute a fire hazard  or why said conditions should not be remedied by the owner or by the city at the expense of the owner of said property at said hearing the city and the property owner may introduce such witnesses as are deemed necessary  41701   2105 determination by board  time allowance for remedying the violation  appeal a if the property owner or duly authorized agent elects to protest the notice as set forth in the preceding sections and appears before the board the board shall determine whether the condition described in sections 25103 and 25104 hereof and in the notice to owner does or does not exist b if the board determines that the situation and condition as set forth in sections 25103 and 25104 and in the notice to owner does not exist then such notice to owner shall be considered forthwith null and void and of no effect and no action shall be taken by any agency of the city in regard to such condition at that time and the filing fee shall be refunded c if the board shall determine that the condition described in sections 25103 and 25104 and the notice to owner does exist then from the date of such determination by the board the owner shall have ten calendar days to remedy the violation in accordance with the citys instructions on the notice upon the failure of the owner to remedy the violation within the ten calendar days specified the city manager or designee shall direct the appropriate agency of the city to remedy such violation as if no protest had been made d appeal an appeal shall be to the city council and must be taken within five calendar days after an order decision or determination is made by the board the appeal shall be limited to the record before the board the appeal shall be filed on a form prescribed by the city and shall be accompanied by a $5000 filing fee which shall be refunded if the owner prevails in the appeal the city council may upon appeal reverse affirm or modify any order or determination of the board if the city council affirms the decision of the board then the owner shall have ten calendar days from date of the city council hearing to remedy the violation  41701   2105 collection of costs and records  secured property after causing the violation to be remedied the city manager or designee shall certify the expense incurred in remedying the violation whereupon such expense plus a charge of $10000 to cover city administrative expenses shall become payable within 30 days from completion of the work after which a special assessment lien and charge will be made upon the property which shall be payable with interest at the rate allowable by law beginning 30 days from the date of such certification is made until paid the costs shall include all expenditures by the state division of forestry the city or their authorized agents for labor supplies equipment use contractors and services related to implementing the mitigation plan for the property and the cost of filing the lien such lien shall take priority and be enforceable in the same manner as a tax lien in favor of the city and may be satisfied at any time by payment thereof including accrued interest notice of such lien shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the circuit court and recorded upon the public records of flagler county florida if the subject property is secured by locks or otherwise the city shall have the authority to enter such property for purposes of remedying the violative condition and any additional costs incurred by the city in gaining access to the property or in resecuring the property after cleaning shall be considered expenses of remedying the condition  41701 imminent fire danger nothing in this article shall prevent the city from taking all actions necessary to fight fires when there is imminent fire danger including but not limited to clearing brush from private property without notice nothing in this ordinance shall prevent the city from acting pursuant to fs  59002 where necessary  41701 no tree permit required  other restrictions and requirements applicable no permit shall be required for remedying the violations as required by this article  however the requirements restrictions and limitations imposed by other sections of city applicable provisions of the land development code pertaining to environmental preservation tree removal permits change of grade etc shall be applicable in the event of any conflict between this section and any other provision of this applicable provision of the land development code the other sections of this applicable provisions of the land development code shall prevail and govern  41701 article v  sparklers and fireworks footnotes  3  editors note  adopted dec 5 200 amended the adding provisions that were not specifically amendatory at the editors discretion said provisions were included herein as  2513525143 former art v  25135 pertained to open fires and fireworks and derived from  adopted  authority this article is enacted pursuant to the home rule charter of palm coast and florida statutes  12506 short title this article shall be known as and may be cited as the city of palm coast fireworks   12506 intent the purpose and intent of this article is to promote protect and improve the health safety welfare and quality of life of the citizens of the city of palm coast florida by establishing regulations governing the sale purchase and utilization of fireworks and sparklers within the city  12506 definitions the following words and terms shall have the meanings set out below unless the context clearly indicates otherwise fire district means the city fire rescue department or any corporations including flagler county with whom the city contracts for fire protections services fire district official means the city fire chief or designee fireworks means and includes any combustible or explosive composition or substance or combination of substances or unless otherwise exempt any articles prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion explosion deflagration or detonation the term includes blank cartridges and toy cannons in which explosives are used firecrackers torpedoes skyrockets roman candles dago bombs or any fireworks containing any explosives or flammable compound or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance fireworks does not include any item listed in 4c florida statutes manufacturer means any person firm partnership or corporation engaged in the manufacture or construction of sparklers or fireworks in the city proximate audience means an audience to an indoor display and which is closer to pyrotechnic devices than allowed by national fire protection association nfpa edition pyrotechnic operator means the person responsible for pyrotechnic safety and who controls initiates or otherwise creates special effects the operator is also responsible for storing setting up and removing pyrotechnic material or devices after a performance pyrotechnic means the science of controlled exothermic chemical reactions that are timed to create the effects of heat gas sound dispersion of aerosols emission of visible electromagnetic radiation or a combination of these effect to provide the maximum effect from least volume pyrotechnic material means a chemical mixture used in the entertainment industry to produce visible or audible effects by combustion deflagration or detonation such chemical mixture predominately consists of solids capable of producing a controlled selfsustaining and selfcontained exothermic chemical reaction that results in heat gas sound light or a combination of these effects the chemical reaction functions without external oxygen retailer means any person firm partnership or corporation who at a fixed place of business is engaged in the business of selling sparklers to consumers at retail seasonal retailer means any person firm partnership or corporation engaged in the business of selling sparklers at retail from june 20 from december 10 of each year from a temporary location including but not limited to tents storefronts and open air sales sparkler means a device which emits showers of sparks upon burning does not contain any explosive compound does not detonate or explode is handheld or groundbased cannot propel itself air and contains nor more than 100 grams of chemical compound which produces sparks upon burning any sparkler that is not approved by the state fire marshal is classified as fireworks  12506 storage and sale of sparklers  registration and permit required a sparklers shall be stored and sold in the city in accordance with the zoning laws fire prevention code license laws of the city and permits issued by the fire district official or state division of fire marshal having jurisdiction and all other state and local laws b all manufacturers distributors retailers seasonal retailers and wholesalers of sparklers shall show proof of current registration with the state division of fire marshal to the fire district official upon request c all manufacturers distributors wholesalers retailers and seasonal retailers of sparklers must obtain an annual permit from the city prior to selling sparklers in the city d a retailer or seasonal retailer who sells sparklers at more than one retail location may submit one permit application for all locations within the city by providing the address of each location on the same permit application form or the retailer may submit multiple application forms for each location e nothing herein shall be construed to exempt manufacturers distributors wholesalers retailers or seasonable retailers from compliance with all other applicable zoning licensing building and fire protection requirements of the city f it is prohibited and unlawful to sell sparklers in the city without a permit g each retailer and seasonal retailer shall keep a copy of the permit and state registration at every location where sparklers are sold  12506 prohibition of fireworks  exceptions  permits and regulations a except as provided in 04 or 79107 florida statutes it is prohibited and unlawful for any person firm partnership or corporation to offer for sale at wholesale or retail expose for sale at wholesale or retail or use or explode any fireworks within the city without a city permit b the city manager or designee shall develop an affidavit which all sellers of fireworks within the city shall use to determine the entitlement of any purchaser at retail or wholesale to buy fireworks c the purchaser of any fireworks must furnish to the seller at the time of sale proof of identification and if applicable proof that the purchaser in compliance with florida statutes the seller shall retain a copy of any proof of registration presented d the seller shall maintain a permanent onsite record of all sales including the name and address of each purchaser the form of the purchasers identification presented along with any unique identifier associated with that identification eg drivers license number and where required proof of registration and compliance with florida statutes if the seller determines that registration under florida statutes is not required then the basis for such exception or exemption shall be recorded on a form approved by the fire district official e any person firm partnership or corporation who is not registered with the division of the state fire marshal and who pursuant to florida statutes purchases fireworks for shipment directly out of the state is prohibited from taking possession of such fireworks the seller shall retain the possession of such fireworks and shall be responsible for shipping all fireworks purchased to the purchaser or other recipient at any outofstate point of delivery if an outofstate address is not given to seller for shipment the sale shall be presumed to be unlawful under florida statues as a not for outofstate use sale and is prohibited f it is prohibited and unlawful for any person firm partnership corporation or other entity to sell fireworks for outofstate use and deliver possession of said fireworks to the purchaser by any means other than by shipping the fireworks to the outofstate delivery address g any person firm partnership or corporation who pursuant to rules promulgated by the department of agriculture and consumer services under florida statutes purchases fireworks for frightening birds must provide to the seller documentary evidence stamped by the flagler county sheriffs office the city fire district office or other city designee that the purchaser has complied with the regulations of the state department of agriculture and consumer services and that the purchaser has filed with the sheriff of the county where the fireworks will be used the statement as required by the florida administrative purchaser shall provide to the seller a copy of any statement so filed with the sheriff as required by the florida administrative seller shall maintain a copy of the proof offered in addition to the information required in subsection e above h the purchaser of fireworks to be used by a railroad or other transportation agency shall provide a copy of the business license or other government issued document evidencing that the purchaser is a legitimate railroad or transportation agency a commercial drivers license by itself does not meet the requirements of this section a copy of this document shall be maintained by the seller i the purchaser of fireworks to be used in quarrying or for blasting or other industrial use must produce a copy of the quarry or mine permit or business license or other governmentally issued document showing that the purchaser is operating a mine quarry or other industrial enterprise the seller shall maintain a copy of this proof and note the use for which the fireworks shall be used the seller shall also record the location where the fireworks will be used the purchaser of fireworks to be used in a public display must produce a copy of the current permit from a county or municipality and the seller must keep a copy of this permit with the record of sale j all appropriate local and state permits registration certificates and licenses must be displayed at each retail wholesale distributing or manufacturing site k the seller shall maintain copies of the records required by this article at the location where the sale took place for a period of four years from the date of the sale if the location of the sale was in a temporary facility the records shall be maintained at that site for the duration of the existence of the temporary facility and thereafter for the remainder of the four years in a location within the city which location shall be listed on the application for city permit these records shall be available and provided immediately upon request for inspection by fire district official or law enforcement in the event that the sales location other than a temporary site closes or moves the records required by this section to be retained shall be stored at a location in the city where they will be readily available for inspection by the fire district official the city or its designee the seller shall advise the city of any change in the location of these records  12506 use of fireworks it is prohibited and unlawful for a person or entity to use explode or store fireworks in the city unless 1 the person or entity first obtains all appropriate permits for the display of fireworks or pyrotechnics  or 2 the use is by a railroad or other transporting agency for illumination or signal purposes or the use is associated with quarrying blasting or another industrial purpose in accordance with florida statutes  or 3 the use in conjunction with a bona fide agricultural use as provided in florida statutes  12506 display of fireworks a the supervised public display of fireworks as contemplated in florida statutes is permitted if the requirements of this section have been met all displays must be in accordance with the the display of fireworks as set out in nfpa nfpa edition b an application for a permit to operate a display of fireworks in accordance with this article shall be made with the fire district official at least 15 days prior to the scheduled date of the event the application shall be in a form prepared by the city c evidence of financial responsibility in the form of proof of insurance at a type and level approved by the citys risk manager shall be provided to the city at the time of application d application and payment fees shall be established by resolution adopted by the city council e the fire district official or designee will determine if the display of fireworks as proposed by the applicant will provide an acceptable degree of life safety based upon the terrain available fire protection features or other requirements deemed appropriate by the fire district official f the fire official district official may as a condition of the permit require onsite uniformed district personnel specialized fire protection equipment or extra suppression equipment any costs incurred to comply with the conditions of the permit will be the responsibility of the applicant g a permit may be revoked by the fire marshal fire district official or their designee at any time if the permittee fails to comply with the terms and conditions of the permit h permits are not transferable  12506 penalties and enforcement the city may enforce the provisions of this article by any means permitted by law and the penalty for violation of this article shall be the maximum permitted by state law  12506 use of fireworks and sparklers during fire bans during periods of flagler county issued fire bans the sale use andor discharge of fireworks and sparklers are prohibited  6308 floods article i  in general franchise regulations footnotes  1  cross reference administration ch 2  businesses and business regulations ch 16  emergency services ch 23  environment ch 24  impact fees ch 29  streets roads and other public places ch 42  traffic and vehicles ch 44  utilities ch 49  land development code app a article i  in general article ii  catv system short title this division shall be known as the city of palm coast master cable tv regulatory   31400 purposes the purpose of this article is to establish the procedures and criteria for the granting and renewal of nonexclusive cable television franchises within the city this article further establishes the minimum standards for installation and operation of such franchises and supplements the standards for existing cable operators this division additionally protects and controls the use of public easements and rightsofway by cable tv operators these criteria and standards are enacted to promote the public health safety and welfare of the citizens of the city residing in the unincorporated area of the city and to assure compliance with applicable state and federal law  31400 definitions the following words terms or phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where context clearly indicates a different meaning cable tv system means a system of antennae cables wires lines towers wave guides fiber optics conductors converters equipment or other facilities designed constructed or wired for the purpose of transmitting audio signals digital signals or visual images to and from persons and subscribers in the franchise area except systems exempted by state law under fs   gross revenue means any and all compensation and other consideration derived directly by a franchise operator from subscribers for cable tv service including but not limited to installation fees disconnect and reconnect fees and fees for cable service paid by subscribers transfer means any sale conveyance gift or other disposition of any right title or interest in a franchise any material change in the persons constituting the controlling interest of the franchise operator for example shareholders shall be deemed a transfer transfers shall not include assignments by cable operators of their franchises to any entity that is a parent subsidiary or affiliate corporation of the cable operator  provided such corporation existed as of the date of the initial franchise authorization for the cable operator or if not that the new subsidiary corporation receives all of the assets of the franchise holder and the same is certified to the city by a senior official of the franchise holder  31400 necessity of franchise it shall be unlawful for any person to construct or operate a cable tv system in the city excluding the area of its municipalities without a franchise granted by the city the issuance of a franchise shall authorize the cable tv operator to install construct maintain and operate a cable tv system under over across and upon the public easements and rightsofway in the city subject to the requirements and restrictions provided herein  31400 construction of system a no construction shall take place within city rightsofway or property without the prior written approval of the city manager or designee b the franchise operator shall file with the city manager or designee for approval plans and specifications for the location or relocation of all facilities within the franchise area such facilities shall be located or relocated so as not to obstruct or interfere with the use of streets alleys easements and other public ways and places or other utilities or structures already installed or hereafter to be installed subject at all times to the lawful police power of the city street or pavement cuts to install conduit are prohibited unless the franchise operator obtains prior approval from the city manager or designee according to the procedures and standards of the citys utility accommodation ordinance c the franchise operator may make attachments to poles already in existence within the city to the extent existing poles are insufficient for its purposes or if the cable operator is unable to negotiate agreements satisfactory to it for use of existing poles the cable operator may erect its own poles or underground conduit as necessary for the construction and maintenance of its cable tv system subject to the approval of the city manager or designee for all such poles or conduit to be placed within city rightofway or city property no poles however shall be allowed or installed by the cable operator in areas or neighborhoods where utilities are placed below ground the use of city poles towers or other electrical facilities owned by the city if authorized by the city manager or designee shall not interfere with the use of such poles towers or electrical facilities d all underground conduit in city rightsofway or property shall have a minimum cover of 24 inches below ground and 30 inches below pavement crossings of storm drains shall be under the pipe or structure with a minimum clearance of 12 inches below the bottom of the storm drain pipe all underground conduit off city rightsofway to a subscriber shall be a minimum of 12 inches below ground unless the subscriber consents otherwise in writing to less than 12 inches such writing need not be a formal document but may be a form used by the cable operator so long as the document establishes that the subscriber or his or her agent consents to a depth of less than 12 inches e all construction installation maintenance and repair shall conform to city building codes and ordinances including but not limited to the tree protection provisions of the citys land development regulations road damage ordinance and utility accommodation ordinance f all construction installation and repair work shall be carried out with due regard for safety to surrounding property whether public or private the franchise operator shall employ safety measures relating to traffic whether pedestrian or vehicular during such work which are consistent with series 600 of the florida department of transportation standard index or the uniform traffic control device manual whichever is more stringent any use of safety barricades shall conform to the uniform traffic control device manual the franchise operator shall be responsible for any damage to bridges sidewalks inlets and drainage structures caused by its operations such damage must be repaired according to current standards any damage to pavement due to the franchise operators work must be repaired by the operator with a permanent paved patch in accordance with current standards within five working days after the work is completed g all construction installation maintenance or repair work shall be conducted in a manner that minimizes the disruption of telephone electric gas water sewer cable or other utility services the franchise operator shall provide reasonable notice to the providers of such services so existing systems can be marked h in the performance of such work the franchise operator shall insure that the safety functioning and appearance of the property worked on is not adversely affected any property that sustains alteration or damage by reason of the construction installation maintenance or repair of the cable tv system shall be restored to its immediate preexisting condition reasonably and promptly subject to any device or equipment installed in the event restoration is not accomplished promptly the franchise operator shall fully and promptly compensate the owner for such damage i if during the term of the franchise the city elects to alter or modify the grade or use of any city road rightofway or property the franchise operator on reasonable notice by the city shall remove or relocate permanently or temporarily as the circumstances require the affected facility or equipment at the operators expense j all construction installation maintenance or repair work shall further conform to any requirements of the state of florida and the federal communications commission k all obligations provided above shall apply to the employees agents or independent contractors working for the franchise operator the franchise operator shall be liable to assure that its employees agents or independent contractors perform their work in accordance with this regulatory ordinance this provision shall not be construed to create liability on the part of the cable operator to third parties  31400 design and operation a the cable tv system shall be designed and operated so as to meet all fcc requirements franchise operators also are specifically subject to fs      relating to use of rightofway repair to public roads and relocations  fs   cable tv franchising requirements  fs  29 prohibiting interference with other utility systems responsibility for damage to other public utilities and construction requirement to meet national electrical   and such other florida statutes or their successors as may apply to a franchise operator b franchise operators shall make available and be capable of initially transmitting at least 30 channels for delivery to subscribers upon commencement of operation this provision shall not be construed to require a franchise operator to carry at no charge a signal for a television station which received remuneration from or on behalf of the recipient of the signal including signals now known as teletext or extravision or other similar programs for which a charge is made by the television station c to the extent required by the fcc or federal law a franchise operator shall designate channel capacity for commercial use by persons who are not affiliated with the operator a franchise operator may use any unused channel capacity designated pursuant to this section until an agreement is reached to lease that capacity if a person who is not affiliated with a franchise operator seeks to lease channel capacity pursuant to this section then a franchise operator shall establish the price terms and conditions of such lease which will be at least sufficient to assure that the lease will not adversely affect the operation financial condition or market development of the cable system d franchise operators shall provide one exterior cable service connection outlet for basic service without installation or monthly charges to all public schools all public libraries all cityowned recreational buildings the city courthouses and annexes and all other buildings and facilities owned by the city and used by the city for the delivery of city services to the public  provided that such facilities are within the franchise area of the franchise operator such facility is contiguous to any main lateral cable system of the operator and the connections are specifically requested by the city manager or designee e at the request of the city manager or designee franchise operators shall provide the city without charge one operative television channel over the system this channel is to be provided solely for the city and other governmental bodies within the city in order to transmit civic and school programs lectures shows announcements city meetings or meetings of their committees educational amusement or recreational information and all other lawful news information which the city desires at any and all times all such use of this channel shall be coordinated among the various government entities served by the system such coordination shall be city manager or designee f franchise operators shall furnish the city free of charge an emergency override capability and alert warning system by which city officials may interrupt by audio or visual crawl message or similar methods all cable system programs simultaneously to either broadcast emergency information directly or to direct viewers to tune to a
